metadata.h1: I taught applied AI to 300 business students in 10 different schools.

all_paragraphs: For the past year I’ve been lucky enough to teach applied AI to a variety of business students in France.
Teaching AI for people that have no background in math/statistics is more difficult that it might seem.
But it is by far the most interesting topic to tackle.

It involves such broad and numbers of aspects that are critical for future business leaders in terms of economic perspective of course but also ethically, and philosophically, that trying to get the essence of that subject and teach it was fascinating.
I suppose I learned more than my students and I decided to share what I found out.
I also survey 100 of them.
This article has a pedagogical objective and those lessons could actually be applied to any kind of topic and not specifically to AI.
I had 10 different classes. The opportunity for me to A/B test my intro speech.

Guess what, when I started the course with the simplest explanation of why they needed to pay attention about this course, they were more involved. At least in the first 5 minutes. And the first 5 minutes determines the rest of your entire course.
You know what they say, you never get a second chance to make a first good impression. Well, it’s true.
For AI specifically the intro went like this :
Hey, who are you ? And what are you talking to me ?
Trust is everything, if they trust you are competent in a subject they are interested in, they’ll probably want to continue listening.
Why are we creating AI ? Leads to what is AI fundamentally ? That leads to what is an innovation anyway ?
An innovation has always the objective to expand a human attribute.
So what superpower are we trying to give with AI ?
Hint: It’s in the word AI..
Once we know that we’re trying to expand our intelligence by giving machines the ability to think and act like humans, we can try to understand “the how-to” behind it.
Starts with the customer wants and works backends to the technology, Steve Jobs
Start with the application and work backwards to the theory.
Actually system design is one of the most important skill in software engineering and it’s mostly thinking about how to architect complex products.
When you think about architecture, you think about structure and processes.
It turns out, most of the thing we know can be designed as a 3 stage process in life :
This is an example of how i combined 4 and 5.
Then you deconstruct the system by asking the right questions.
Well fundamentally, it’s about seeing and anticipating.
Well we need to learn how to do it.
Here’s come the machine learning part.
Take a well-known concept and apply it to your expert domain.
For instance with AI, a useful metaphor and comparison concept that i came up with is:

Building : To build a house (your output), you need raw materials like cement and stone (your data), you need tools like a cement mixer truck (your algorithms and frameworks) and you need careful guidelines (your models) to follow a plan.
You can apply that to cooking, studying and many more activities…
I designed case studies in pairs rather than in groups. It turned out to be much more efficient.
Masterclass has really inspired me on that one.
There’s nothing more efficient than real world-class experts bringing practicality to your applied scientific course.
I created a course on what learnings could we draw from chess to business strategy in AI and from poker to AI decision-making.
I used to design accountability case studies around Shark tank shows. Students were quite hooked.
Games, vidéos, debates, sports are powerful learning stimulators.
Google AI provide useful experiments to test AI tools in live classrooms for instance.
MIT Moral machine regarding ethics in AI was a powerful engagement tool for instance.
Build sections from scratch with their answers.
Your only limitation is your imagination.
Sometimes students won’t engage but it will always teach you why.
Every 30 min i used to take 1 min to sum up what learned so far.
Especially when you course is build bottom up and you need the to understand what’s coming next.
Business students don’t really want to have their question answered. They want to understand how to answer in any given situation.
One exercise that i found particularly useful was to state the extremely wide and open-ended question : How AI will impact society ?
They had to come up with answer and found out that it couldn’t be that easy when stated that way.
This is the answer i provided :
They didn’t like it and me too.
Try to find why they want to listen to you in the first place.
Call them by their first name if you can.
Always state that their questions are really relevant.
Try 1 on 1 quality session prior during group studies if you can.
Thank you for reading this, feel free to connect with me on Linkedin to talk about AI.
